indices returns market-history

6.1 What is an Index?

  • Definition: An index is a "basket" used to measure the overall performance of a group of stocks.
  • FunctionÔºö
    1. Investors commonly use it to judge overall market movements.
    2. Can directly invest in the entire market through index funds (ETFs).
  • AnalogyÔºö
    • Single stock = one dish
    • Stock index = entire menu (market average level)

6.2 Three Major US Indices

Index Components Characteristics Historical Returns Suitable For
Dow Jones Industrial Average (DJIA) 30 blue-chip stocks Established large companies, mainly industrial/financial Long-term annualized ~5‚Äì7% Conservative investors
S&P 500 500 large companies Best represents US economy Long-term annualized ~8‚Äì10% Long-term investors
Nasdaq Composite 3000+ companies High tech stock weighting Long-term annualized ~10‚Äì12%, high volatility Tech growth enthusiasts

üëâ ExampleÔºö

  • 2008 Financial Crisis ‚Üí all three indices crashed.
  • 2010‚Äì2021 Tech Bull Market ‚Üí Nasdaq far outperformed S&P.

Region Index Characteristics Risk

üá®üá≥ China Shanghai Composite Index (SSE) Large SOEs, banks, energy companies Policy-driven

üëâ Investment InsightÔºö

  • US market is most suitable for long-term holding ‚Üí stable growth + strong innovation capability.
  • Emerging markets (China, Hong Kong) ‚Üí high volatility, need caution.
  • Global indices (MSCI) ‚Üí diversify risk, suitable for conservative investors.

üìå Extension: Chinese A-Shares and ChiNext

üÄÑ What are A-Shares?

  • Definition: A-shares are stocks listed in mainland China, denominated and traded in RMB.
  • Name OriginÔºö
    • China's securities market was originally divided into A-shares (RMB) and B-shares (foreign currency, USD/HKD denominated).
    • A-shares = market for local investors (mainly mainland Chinese residents).
    • B-shares = early channel for foreigners to invest in China (now less significant).
  • Main ExchangesÔºö
    • Shanghai Stock Exchange (SSE)
    • Shenzhen Stock Exchange (SZSE)

üëâ Can be understood as: A-shares are "domestic RMB stocks", distinguished from international markets like Hong Kong stocks and US stocks.

üöÄ What is ChiNext?

  • Definition: ChiNext is China's high-growth enterprise financing platform, mainly listing tech, innovation, and growth companies.
  • CharacteristicsÔºö
    • Established in 2009, similar to US Nasdaq.
    • Suitable for smaller but promising companies.
    • Higher risk, but also greater return potential.
  • Exchange: On Shenzhen Stock Exchange (SZSE).

üëâ ChiNext can be seen as China's "innovation testing ground", providing investors opportunities to invest in small growth stocks.

6.4 Historical Return Comparison

  • S&P 500Ôºö
    • 1928‚Äì2023 ‚Üí annualized return ~9.8%
    • Amazing compound effect: Long-term holding $10,000 ‚Üí over a million
  • NasdaqÔºö
    • 1990‚Äì2023 ‚Üí annualized return ~11%+
    • But 2000 dot-com bubble dropped 70%
  • Hang Seng IndexÔºö
    • 1987‚Äì2023 ‚Üí annualized return ~5%
    • High volatility, affected by Chinese economy and policy.

üëâ Key ConclusionÔºö

  • US market ‚Üí most stable long-term return source
  • Emerging markets ‚Üí opportunities, but higher risk
  • Global diversification ‚Üí balance growth and risk

6.5 Common Investor Misconceptions

  • ‚ùå Misconception 1: Index investing has no returns.
    • ‚Üí Correct: Indices have long-term annualized ~8‚Äì10%, exceeding most active funds.
  • ‚ùå Misconception 2: Investing in only one country is safest.
    • ‚Üí Correct: Geopolitical and policy risks exist, global diversification is more stable.
  • ‚ùå Misconception 3: Indices = no risk.
    • ‚Üí Correct: Short-term volatility is still severe (e.g., 2008 financial crisis S&P dropped 40%+).

üìò Summary

  • Three major US indices ‚Üí most important reference standards.
  • Other indices (Hong Kong, China, Japan, Global) ‚Üí provide diversification opportunities.
  • Historical experience ‚Üí S&P 500 long-term return rate ~10%, is the "gold standard" for wealth accumulation.
  • Index investing ‚â† no risk, but long-term, it's one of the most stable investment methods.
